I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Viet Nam has requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to 
consider financing a project for constructing two major bridges across the Mekong River at Cao 
Lanh and Vam Cong in southern Viet Nam with access roads and an interconnecting road.1 The 
proposed project forms part of the Second Southern Highway (SSH) which connects Ho Chi 
Minh City (HCMC) through the central Mekong Delta region to the Southern Coastal Region, 
where it joins with the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) Southern Coastal Corridor at Rach 
Gia. During the Country Programming Confirmation Mission for the 2007 program for Viet Nam, 
the Government requested ADB for technical assistance (TA) to assist in the preparation of the 
Central Mekong Delta Region Connectivity Project. In the memorandum of understanding for 
the mission it was agreed that a project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) for the project 
would be included in ADB’s nonlending program for 2007. 
2.  During 21–26 August 2007, a factfinding mission2 from ADB visited Viet Nam to discuss 
the scope and implementation arrangements for the PPTA project. The purpose, scope, and 
implementation  arrangements3  for  the  PPTA  project  were  agreed  in  a  memorandum  of 
understanding between ADB and the Ministry of Transport, signed on 24 August 2007. The 
Government has requested ADB to identify possible cofinancing on concessional terms and 
partial ADB funding from its Asian Development Fund resources for the ensuing project to 
augment the available budget and reduce future loan service. 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Viet Nam is currently experiencing rapid economic growth, based primarily on export 
processing industries and tourism. Between 2003 and 2007 gross domestic product (GDP) grew 
by an average of 8% per year, while exports in the same period grew by an average of about 
20%. The Mekong Delta region is the third-largest industrial center in the country after HCMC 
and  Hanoi,  and  is  based  primarily  on  agro-industry  and  other  light  industries.  Industrial 
production in the Mekong Delta region has accelerated in recent years, from an average annual 
growth rate of 13% in the period 2000–2004 to a growth rate of 24% in 2004–2005. Road traffic 
is growing rapidly in Viet Nam and a key constraint to future development is the availability of 
efficient transport infrastructure with adequate capacity to meet expanding demand. Between 
2000 and 2005, passenger traffic grew at an average rate of about 11% per year and freight 
traffic at an average rate of about 12%. The Government is rapidly upgrading and expanding 
Viet  Nam’s  strategic  transport  infrastructure—especially  highways,  railways,  and  ports—to 
support sustained economic growth. As a result, transport infrastructure investments grew by 
about 12% per year in fixed prices between 2000 and 2006.4 
4.  ADB’s strategy for the transport sector in Viet Nam5 identifies four key issues in the 
transport sector: (i) low efficiency resulting in high transport costs; (ii) weak sustainability due to 
insufficient  financing  and  weak  maintenance  planning;  (iii) increasing  transport  bottlenecks, 
which require innovative financing to be overcome; and (iv) poor road safety, with a fatality rate

5.  The Government is keenly aware of these issues and addresses them at several levels 
in  its  development  strategy.  The  Comprehensive  Poverty  Reduction  and  Growth  Strategy 
recognizes that development of the transport infrastructure is a necessary precondition for 
continued  economic  growth  and  identifies  two  main  needs:  (i) development  of  rural 
infrastructure, including the rural and provincial road network, to create access and the basis for 
widespread and equitable growth; and (ii) development of large-scale infrastructure to sustain 
economic  growth.  The  Socio-Economic  Development  Plan  2006–20107  emphasizes  the 
generation of the economic growth that is required to attain the Millennium Development Goals 
and Viet Nam’s own development goals. It recognizes regional cooperation as a key element in 
attaining  the  economic  growth  target  by  generating  additional  intraregional  trade  and 
investments.  Viet  Nam’s  Transport  Sector  Development  Strategy  emphasizes  (i) targeting 
national  and  international  financial  resources;  (ii) charging  users  of  infrastructure  (where 
possible) to accelerate infrastructure development and improve maintenance; (iii) encouraging 
private  sector  participation  in  infrastructure  development,  operation,  and  maintenance  to 
improve efficiency; (iv) promoting safety and environmental sustainability in transport to reduce 
the social and economic costs of transport; and (v) promoting modernization of infrastructure 
management to improve resource allocation. 
6.  ADB’s strategy in Viet Nam is the reduction of poverty through implementation of an 
economic development strategy that is closely aligned to the Socio-Economic Development 
Plan and its targeted outcomes. The Transport Sector Roadmap in ADB’s country strategy and 
program (2007–2010) for Viet Nam8 addresses the identified issues in three ways: (i) the first 
addresses  the  social  equity  aspects  of  Viet  Nam’s  transport  needs  by  supporting  the 
development of provincial and district networks; (ii) the second addresses critical transport 
needs—such as expressways, railways, and ports—that constrain economic growth in the main 
development  centers  and  are  required  to  facilitate  the  efficient,  safe,  and  environmentally 
sustainable movement of goods and people; and (iii) the third complements the first two by 
bringing  subregional  dimensions  to  the  development  of  the  transport  network  in  terms  of 
connectivity, including multimodal transport modes and competitiveness. The GMS Transport 
Sector  Strategy9  supports  the  third  thrust  by  promoting  smooth  and  efficient  cross-border 
movement of people and goods in an economically, socially, and environmentally sustainable 
manner. 
7.  The  proposed  project  supports  these  strategies  in  several  ways:  (i) the  SSH  runs 
through the central parts of the Mekong River Delta to the west of, and roughly parallel with, the 
existing National Highway 1A (NH1A), thereby providing a shortcut for traffic between HCMC, 
the central Mekong Delta region, and the Southern Coastal Corridor, and connecting the highly 
productive agro-industries in the central Mekong Delta region with important domestic and 
regional markets (notably HCMC and Bangkok) and with shipping ports for export; and (ii) the 
SSH will help alleviate high and rapidly growing traffic on NH1A, which passes several towns 
and cities and cannot be widened without very substantial social and economic impact. 
8.  The SSH passes the Tien Giang channel of the Mekong River at Cao Lanh, and the Hau 
Giang channel of the Mekong River at Vam Cong. The two crossings are currently served by

small vehicle ferries, and the scope for expanding the capacity of the ferry services is limited. 
The PPTA project will help remove this constraint by preparing a project for (i) the construction 
of two high bridges with a combined length of about 4,000 meters (m) to cross the channels,10 
(ii) the construction of about 28 kilometers (km) of access roads including an interconnector 
road between the two bridge sites, and (iii) the construction of toll plazas to collect bridge tolls. 
Similar to the My Thuan Bridge on NH1A, the Government intends to collect road tolls at the 
proposed new bridge crossings to help defray the cost of constructing and maintaining the 
bridges. To provide the flexibility required to meet future traffic demand while keeping initial 
costs down, the SSH will initially be built as a two-lane single carriageway but will be designed 
to expressway standard and will have sufficient right of way to enable future expansion to dual 
carriageway expressway standard when required. At current traffic growth rates this will happen 
within 10 years. The proposed bridges will immediately be built as four-lane dual carriageway to 
avoid construction activities disturbing the marine environment twice within a few years. The 
additional cost of this is offset by avoiding the cost of constructing parallel bridges when the 
road is widened. 
9.  A  number  of  project-specific  issues  have  been  identified  that  will  require  particular 
attention during project preparation. Financing debt service for new infrastructure from road tolls 
is often difficult in the early years after construction, where traffic typically is low and toll 
revenues small. The design minimizes initial cost wherever practicable and the PPTA project 
includes preparation of recommendations for structuring of the ensuing project’s financing to 
minimize the need for Government subsidy. The northern sections of the SSH, from HCMC 
towards the project bridges, are under construction but the southern extension to Rach Gia is 
only at the planning stage with expected completion before 2020. This could constrain traffic in 
the early years until that connection is completed, and could increase the need for Government 
subsidies in the early years of operation. The bridges and the approach roads pass through 
productive agricultural land and significant land acquisition and resettlement will be required. 
The region is inhabited by a significant number of Khmers, who are a minority group and may 
require special attention during project design. These issues are explicitly addressed under the 
PPTA project. The Mekong Delta is a vulnerable environment and environmental management 
must be in place during design and construction to ensure that natural water flows are not 
impeded during or after construction and disturbance of the marine environment is minimized 
during construction. Resolving these diverse issues will require extensive analysis to formulate 
a project that optimally benefits Viet Nam as a whole and the population living in the Mekong 
Delta region in particular. 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
10.  The  impact  of  the  ensuing  project  is  to  provide  a  more  efficient,  safe,  and 
environmentally friendly road transport system between HCMC, the project area and Rach Gia, 
and the GMS Southern Coastal Corridor. The project will provide adequate road capacity to 
sustain continued rapid economic growth in the Mekong River Delta. To achieve this impact, the 
project will construct a section of the SSH (including the two bridges) in order to establish a 
highway network in the region that can be expanded in step with economic development in 
future. 
                                                 
10 The Mekong River is an international waterway under international treaty. The treaty specifies that the 
free headway for passing vessels must be at least 37 m over the high water level.

4   
11.  The purpose of the PPTA project is to finalize the project design to a level suitable for 
ADB financing and agreed upon by the Government and ADB. The PPTA project will provide 
the resources required to prepare the ensuing project and identify adequate mitigation of the 
social, resettlement, and other safeguard issues arising from the project. The PPTA project will 
review and update the feasibility studies that the Government has prepared for the project. It will 
carry out due diligence and propose modifications as required to ensure the feasibility of the 
project while minimizing relevant safeguard concerns. The PPTA project will develop plans for 
(i)  mitigation  of  unavoidable  negative  impacts,  (ii)  monitoring  of  such  impacts,  and  (iii) 
monitoring the effectiveness of mitigation. 
  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The PPTA project will be based on the feasibility studies and preliminary design reports 
prepared for the Ministry of Transport and approved by the prime minister. The PPTA project 
will (i) carry out technical due diligence of the preliminary engineering design and update the 
preliminary  design  as  needed  to  produce  documentation  for  design-build  contract 
documentation; (ii) update the construction cost estimates to current price levels and prepare 
these in ADB’s standard format; (iii) review the scope for revenue from toll collection and 
prepare  preliminary  designs  for  toll  facilities;  (iv) prepare  financial  management  capacity 
assessment  and  procurement  review  of  the  implementing  agency  for  the  ensuing  project; 
(v) review  and  recommend  options  for  financial  structuring  of  the  project  to  minimize  the 
Government subsidy required for the project to meet payments of loan debt services and 
operation;  (vi) perform  economic  and  financial  analysis  to  ascertain  the  project’s  viability, 
subject  to  the  updated  project  cost  and  additional  works  identified  during  PPTA  project 
preparation;  (vii) identify  and  assess  subregional  economic  benefits;  (viii) prepare  bidding 
documents for a design-build contract for the bridges and the associated roads and facilities; 
(ix) address any equity, social and environmental issues associated with the project and its 
subsequent  operation—such  as  resettlement,  traffic  safety,  and  environmental  issues—to 
ensure that the ensuing project will not negatively affect the hydrological capacity of the Mekong 
River or otherwise degrade the project area during or after construction; and (x) prepare the 
environmental impact assessment for the project, a full resettlement plan, an ethnic minority 
development plan or an ethnic minority specific action (depending on the number of ethnic 
Khmer’s affected), and design any other project interventions for monitoring and mitigation of 
negative  impacts,  such  as  barrier  effects  arising  from  the  construction  and  subsequent 
operation of the project. Preparing mitigation will require environmental and social surveys and 
consultation with affected people, local authorities, and nongovernment organizations. 
 
13.  Keys  objectives  of  the  PPTA  project  are  to  (i)  prepare  design-build  contract 
documentation in such a way that the final design imparts minimal negative impacts, thus 
minimizing the need for subsequent mitigation; and (ii) prepare plans to effectively monitor and 
manage unavoidable negative impacts during construction and operation. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The  total  cost  of  the  PPTA  project  is  estimated  at  $1,000,000  equivalent.  The 
Government has requested that ADB finance $800,000 equivalent. The PPTA project will be 
financed on a grant basis by the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The 
Government will finance $200,000 equivalent in local logistic support, counterpart staff, and 
other costs. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan is presented in Appendix 3. The 
Government has been informed that approval of the PPTA project does not commit ADB to 
finance any ensuing project.

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements  
15.  The executing agency for the PPTA project will be the Ministry of Transport. The Viet 
Nam  Road  Administration  will  implement  the  PPTA  project  through  the  My  Thuan  Project 
Management  Unit  (PMU-MT).  The  PMU-MT  has  extensive  experience  with  implementing 
externally funded projects, including the large My Thuan Bridge on the Mekong River (which 
was financed by the Australian Government) and several completed and ongoing ADB-financed 
road sector projects. The PMU-MT has the resources and experience required to effectively 
manage the PPTA project and recruit the consultants. 
 
16.  An international consulting engineering firm will be engaged by ADB using simplified 
technical proposal and quality and cost-based selection, weighting the technical evaluation at 
80% and the financial evaluation at 20%. All recruitment will be in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). The consultant will 
review and develop the ensuing project and prepare the documents required for implementation 
of the project, including (i) bid documents for design-build contracts for the two bridges; (ii) the 
environmental impact assessment, a full resettlement plan, and an ethnic minority development 
plan; and (iii) drafts of the documents required for approval of the project by the Government of 
Viet Nam and ADB. The PPTA project will require about 20 person-months of international 
consultancy  services  and  about  30  person-months  of  national  consultancy  services  with 
expertise in (i) bridge, road, hydrological, and geotechnical engineering; (ii) traffic, financial, and 
economic analyses; (iii) environmental assessment and design; and (iv) resettlement planning. 
The PPTA project is scheduled for initiation in March 2008 with completion in January 2009. 
Outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 4. 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Viet Nam for preparing the Central Mekong Delta Region Connectivity 
Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

I.  POVERTY ISSUES 
A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy 
The road subsector contributes primarily to poverty reduction by enabling sustained economic growth and by providing 
universal  access.  The  Government’s  Comprehensive  Poverty  Reduction  and  Growth  Strategy  (CPRGS)  emphasizes 
development  of  infrastructure  as  a  necessary  condition  for  economic  growth.  The  CPRGS  identifies  two  main  road 
infrastructure development needs: (i) rural infrastructure to move towards universal accessibility, and (ii) development of large-
scale infrastructure to sustain economic growth. Viet Nam’s impressive economic growth has been pro-poor in the past, with 
only marginal increases in inequality, while the proportion of people living below the total poverty line has halved from 58% in 
1993 to 29% in 2002. The proportion of people living below the food poverty line also halved, from 25% to about 13%, 
indicating that even the poorest segments of the population have benefited from economic growth. However, the incidence of 
poverty in Viet Nam is still high in rural areas, where about 35% of people live in poverty. Poverty used to be more pronounced 
in the project area than in Viet Nam on average, but this gap has been shrinking rapidly in the 10 years since economic 
development accelerated. Poverty is more prevalent in ethnic minorities than in the dominant Kinh majority. There is a 
significant Khmer minority in the Mekong Delta. 
B.     Targeting Classification 
1.  Select the targeting classification of the project: 
 
 General Intervention    Individual or Household (TI-H);  Geographic (TI-G);  Non-Income MDGs (TI-M1, M2, etc.) 
 
The project is for construction of an expressway and two major bridges. It will improve the transport of people and cargo over 
medium to long distances, which promotes general economic growth, but is only weakly linked with any particular group in 
terms of ethnicity, gender, income, social status, and geography. 
C.  Poverty Analysis4 
1.  If the project is classified as TI-H, or if it is policy-based, what type of poverty impact analysis is needed? n/a. 
2.  What resources are allocated in the PPTA/due diligence? About 3 person-months of international expert time, about 6 
person-months of national expert time, and budget for surveys are allocated for resettlement and ethnic minority planning. 
This will be implemented by the PPTA consulting team. 
3.  If GI, is there any opportunity for pro-poor design (e.g., social inclusion subcomponents, cross subsidy, pro-poor 
governance, and pro-poor growth)? None. 
II.  SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT ISSUES 
A.  Initial Social Analysis 
Based on existing information: 
1.  Who are the potential primary beneficiaries of the project? How do the poor and the socially excluded benefit from the 
project? Road transport users (passengers and cargo owners), producers, and consumers of products from the central 
Mekong Delta region are the primary beneficiaries. 
2.  What are the potential needs of beneficiaries in relation to the proposed project? Road transport users will save time and 
money by having access to a shorter, faster, and more direct route, and by having the option to divert from congested 
routes. These savings will reduce the costs of distribution which will benefit producers and consumers. 
3.  What are the potential constraints in accessing the proposed benefits and services, and how will the project address 
them? Access to the project area via the existing National Highway is a significantly longer journey than accessing via 
the proposed project road. Traffic on the existing highway is approaching capacity which in future will lead to increasing 
congestion.

12  Appendix 4 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  Purpose and Scope  
1.  Purpose 
1.  The purpose of the project is to (i) prepare a design-build project for the construction of 
two new bridges across the Mekong River (at Cao Lanh and Vam Cong) based on the feasibility 
studies and preliminary design reports prepared by the Ministry of Transport, and (ii) prepare 
the scope for a subsequent design and supervision contract encompassing (a) the final design 
of about 28 kilometers (km) of access roads, (b) an engineering check of the designs prepared 
under the design-build contracts for the two bridges, and (c) supervision of the bridge and road 
works. 
2.  Key objectives of the assignment are to (i) prepare the contract documentation in such a 
way  that  the  final  design  imparts  minimal  negative  impacts,  thus  minimizing  the  need  for 
subsequent mitigation; and (ii) prepare plans to effectively monitor and manage unavoidable 
negative impacts during construction and operation. 
2.  Scope 
3.  An  international  consulting  firm  in  cooperation  with  a  local  consulting  firm  will  be 
recruited to undertake the following tasks. 
(i)  Review the preliminary feasibility study prepared by the Ministry of Transport, 
and confirm that the proposed design for the connecting roads and the proposed 
bridges are appropriate in terms of the overall transport planning for the highway 
network in the Mekong Delta. 
(ii)  Update traffic survey data, including vehicle counts, origin-destination surveys, 
and axle load surveys. 
(iii)  Perform technical due diligence of the preliminary engineering design and update 
the preliminary design. 
(iv)  Update the construction cost estimates to current price level using the Asian 
Development Bank’s (ADB’s) format. 
(v)  Review the scope for revenue from toll collection and prepare preliminary design 
for required toll facilities. 
(vi)  Prepare a financial management capacity assessment and procurement review 
of the implementing agency for the ensuing project. 
(vii)  Review and recommend options for financial structuring of the project to ensure 
that loan debt services and operating costs require minimal Government subsidy. 
(viii)  Identify  and  assess  subregional  economic  benefits,  perform  economic  and 
financial analysis to ascertain the project’s viability subject to the updated project 
cost and additional works required, and perform risk and sensitivity analyses. 
(ix)  Prepare bidding documents using ADB’s sample design-build contract format for 
the two bridges. Bidding documents must make use of ADB’s standard bidding 
documents. 
(x)  Prepare an environmental impact assessment for the project that meets the 
requirements of ADB’s Environment Policy (2002). 
(xi)  Prepare a full resettlement plan that meets the requirements of ADB’s Involuntary 
Resettlement Policy (1995) and either an ethnic minority development plan or 
and ethnic minority specific action as required. 
(xii)  Determine equity, social issues and negative external factors which would be 
associated with the project and its subsequent operation (such as resettlement,

Appendix 4  13 
barrier effects for local traffic, traffic safety, and environmental issues), especially 
negative impacts during and after construction on the hydrological capacity of the 
Mekong  River  and  the  marine  environment  in  the  Mekong  Delta.  Local 
authorities, nongovernment organizations, and civil society will be consulted to 
ensure that all relevant interventions are identified. 
(xiii)  Design project interventions for monitoring and mitigation of negative impacts 
associated with construction and subsequent operation of the project. 
(xiv)  Determine the extent of unexploded ordinance contamination of the project site. 
Determine appropriate measures to survey and clear the project site prior to 
commencement of construction.  
(xv)  Based on the work performed above, prepare an investment plan for submission 
to the Government of Viet Nam that meets all relevant Government regulations at 
the time of project preparation.  
(xvi)  Prepare a project bidding plan for submission to the Government of Viet Nam 
conforming to all relevant Government regulations. The bidding plan must include 
the following information: (a) the division of the project into bid packages, (b) cost 
estimates for each bid package and the sources of finance, (c) selection criteria 
for bidders and the bidding mode to be applied to each bid package, (d) a 
procurement schedule for each bidding package, (e) the type of contract for each 
bidding package, and (f) the duration of each contract. 
3.  Expertise Required 
4.  The consulting services component is expected to require a team of nine international 
consultants and seven domestic consultants with expertise in (i) bridge, road, hydrological, and 
geotechnical  engineering;  (ii)  traffic,  financial,  and  economic  analysis;  (iii)  environmental 
assessment and design; and (iv) resettlement planning. A total of about 20 person-months of 
international consultancy services and about 30 person-months of national consultancy services 
are foreseen. 
B.  Schedule 
5.  The assignment will be implemented over 10 months starting in April 2008 and ending in 
January 2009. 
C.  Deliverables 
6.  The deliverables from the project are 
(i)  an inception report and subsequent bimonthly progress reports; 
(ii)  a technical due-diligence report including a traffic safety audit report and revised 
construction cost estimate; 
(iii)  a toll study and financial structuring report; 
(iv)  a financial management assessment report; 
(v)  an economic and financial evaluation report; 
(vi)  an environmental impact assessment report; 
(vii)  an environmental management plan; 
(viii)  a resettlement plan including an ethnic minority action plan; 
(ix)  design-build bidding documents for the two bridges; 
(x)  an investment plan and bidding plan for submission to the Government; and 
(xi)  a  final  report  which  will  include  a  draft  report  and  recommendation  of  the 
President for the ensuing project.
